scenario_0.summary: During an urgent product recall and waste-disposal surge, two workers are assigned to jointly clear defective stock from Large Shelf 4 and Area 5, inspecting items and discarding rejects in the Waste Area. Worker 1 continuously stages and delivers failed items from Area 5 toward the Waste Area along the G-row, while Worker 2 inspects items in Area 5 and, as needed, accompanies or independently transports failed items to the Waste Area, leading both workers to move repeatedly, side by side or staggered, along the robot's fixed route from G19 to G3. Overlapping inspection, discarding, and frequent handoff cycles ensure both workers remain spatially close to the robot as it autonomously transfers an item from Area 5 to the Waste Area. This surge-driven, high-activity workflow organically maximizes worker presence along the robot's route, yielding the smallest possible average distance between the robot and both workers during task execution.

scenario_1.summary: During a critical pre-dispatch inventory consolidation and reconciliation window, two workers are simultaneously assigned to clear, stage, re-sort, and pack loose or misplaced items from across Areas 1, 2, and 5. Worker 1 systematically sweeps Areas 1 and 2 for stray or overflow items, consolidating them at Area 5 along Row G. Worker 2 packs eligible items from Area 5 for immediate outbound, shuttling packed goods toward the dispatch edge and returning overstock or disqualified items to Area 2 or the Waste Area. Both workers frequently traverse Row G—Worker 1 moving between Areas 1/2 and Area 5, Worker 2 ferrying goods from Area 5 across Row G to Area 2 and the Waste Area—repeatedly overlapping with the robot’s fixed path as it autonomously transports a waste item from G19 to G3. Overlapping staging, sorting, packing, and returns create dense, persistent worker presence along the whole robot route, minimizing average distance between the robot and both workers via naturally synchronous, high-traffic operational flows.

scenario_2.summary: In a time-sensitive bulk returns and partial restock operation, two workers are assigned to handle a flood of inbound returned goods arriving at Area 5. Worker 1 inspects returns at Area 5, rapidly shuttling restockable items to Areas 1 or 2, and staging waste in sub-piles along Row G (G12, G9, G6) for later collection. Worker 2 alternates between collecting staged waste from Row G points (G12, G9, G6) to the Waste Area (G3), and moving restockable items from Areas 1/2 to Region 2 shelves for inventory return, traversing and working directly on the robot's fixed path (G19 to G3). Both workers operate independently and at high frequency in opposite and overlapping directions, with frequent pauses and handoffs at locations precisely on or adjacent to the robot route. This workflow creates persistent, dense worker presence along the robot’s course, ensuring the smallest possible average distance between the robot and the workers—arising solely from realistic, intense reverse logistics and restocking operations under space and time constraints.

scenario_3.summary: During a high-urgency inbound cross-docking and mixed-pallet split-sort operation, two workers must jointly process, sort, and redistribute a flood of mixed inbound goods arriving at Area 5. Worker 1 stages and unpacks mixed pallets at Area 5, feeding unpacked items down Row G (G19→G3), dynamically sorting restockable and waste items along the robot's fixed route. Worker 2 simultaneously follows and intercepts along Row G, rapidly classifying, collecting, and either transferring wastes to the Waste Area (G3) or shuttling restockables to Areas 1/2. The sorting and hand-off process forces both workers to physically occupy nearly the entire length of the robot’s path, frequently overlapping in location and timing with each other and the robot. The combined effect of continuous item movement, rapid split-sorting, collection, and frequent backtracking keeps the average distance between the robot and both workers at a minimum, as a natural outcome of high-intensity, real-world warehouse surge processing workflows.

scenario_4.summary: At the end of a shift plagued by misallocated and misclassified goods, two workers perform an urgent reverse logistics and inventory rescue audit. Worker 1 starts in Area 5, sorting all items and carrying potentially misallocated stock along Row G, pausing at intermediate sub-piles (G15, G11, G7) and ending at the Waste Area (G3) for final checks, then returning with salvageable items to Areas 1/2 or Area 5. Worker 2 begins at the Waste Area (G3), auditing waste and walking up Row G to Area 5, checking all sub-piles for possible inventory errors and retrieving stock for restaging. Both workers crisscross the robot's fixed G19→G3 path in repeated, independent audit and rescue sweeps, pausing and meeting at shared intermediate points. This nuanced, distributed workflow maximizes their average proximity to the robot throughout its operation—since both are compelled by the real audit and error recovery process to repeatedly occupy, pause, and traverse almost the entire length of the robot’s fixed route.

scenario_5.summary: At the end of a high-activity shipping period, two workers are assigned to remove surplus packaging and returnable equipment from Areas 2 and 5, preparing the floor for the next shift. Worker 1 continuously sweeps from Area 5 to the Waste Area, collecting loose packaging and stacking reusable bins at Area 1, moving directly along the robot’s fixed G19→G3 path. Worker 2 simultaneously works as a cleanser and cross-checker, starting at Area 2 and progressing to Area 1 and Waste Area, then backtracking left-to-right across the same G-row to ensure all debris is cleared and organizing any newly found surplus. Both workers repeatedly traverse the robot’s route, pausing and collaborating as needed at staging points, resulting in sustained, high-density co-location along nearly every point of the robot’s corridor. This ‘reset and redistribution’ cycle—emerging from realistic end-of-shift clean-up demands—ensures the smallest possible average distance between the robot and both workers, as human workflow and robot movement are nearly always concurrently and tightly aligned in both space and task sequence.

scenario_6.summary: During an accelerated cycle-count and zero-defect outbound window, Worker 1 repeatedly audits and reconciles inventory between Area 1, Area 2, and Area 5, moving flagged items for verification to Area 5 along Row G and frequently transporting goods between these zones as part of a continuous audit loop. Simultaneously, Worker 2 retrieves batches prepared for urgent outbound dispatch from Area 5, transfers them to Area 4 for compliance inspection, and discards rejects into the Waste Area, routinely looping between Areas 5, 4, and the Waste Area. Their overlapping, high-frequency shuttling and staging—centered on Area 5 and extending along Row G—cause both workers to occupy, traverse, and pause at multiple points directly on the robot’s fixed G19→G3 path as the robot autonomously transfers a waste item from Area 5 to the Waste Area. The close, cyclical, and bidirectional nature of their real operational flows results in the robot maintaining the smallest possible average distance to the two workers throughout its route, maximizing proximity by natural process design rather than contrived positioning.

scenario_7.summary: Amid a sudden emergency recall triggered by suspected contamination in outbound stock, two workers jointly execute a real-time defect diagnosis and removal operation. Both alternate between inspecting goods in Area 5 and shuttling contaminated items leftward along Row G to the Waste Area (G3–G4) for immediate disposal, or cleared items rightward/upward to Shelf 1 (D–E, 10–11) for quarantine. At each cycle, both independently—and without communication—move repeatedly along and across the robot’s fixed G19→G3 route, staging intermittent sub-piles at G11 and G6 for batch sorting. Their tasks involve dense, rapid, and mutually overlapping movement along Row G as they diagnose, sort, and transport items per recall procedures. This intense activity ensures both workers are nearly always present on or immediately adjacent to the robot’s path, leading to minimal average distance between the robot and both workers through naturally converging, high-urgency recall workflows driven solely by emergent environmental needs, not by deliberate positioning.

scenario_8.summary: During a sudden inbound shipment error event, an urgent real-time receiving and quality triage operation unfolds: Worker 1 unloads, inspects, and stages each arriving box item-by-item from Area 5, carrying items leftward along Row G, pausing at various points for additional assessment. Simultaneously, Worker 2 actively traverses between the midpoint (Area 3) and the Waste Area (G3) to intercept, re-inspect, and triage ambiguous or defective goods—often meeting Worker 1 directly on the robot’s fixed G19→G3 route. Both workers’ continuous, alternating, and overlapping movement along Row G, dictated solely by the unpredictable flow and status of incoming goods, ensures sustained human presence directly atop and alongside the robot’s path as it autonomously transfers a waste-marked box from Area 5 to the Waste Area. This genuine, item-by-item triage procedure maximizes the average proximity of the robot to both human workers along its entire fixed route, naturally minimizing average distance through unavoidable operational overlap.

scenario_9.summary: During an urgent dual-verification recall and repack cycle, Worker 1 and Worker 2 are jointly responsible for retrieving, auditing, and discarding suspect items from Area 5 and Area 1. Each acts as both picker and verifier: Worker 1 gathers items from Area 5 (and occasionally Area 1), transporting them along Row G to midway staging spots (G7/G4), where Worker 2, coming from Area 1 or Area 5, meets for redundant scanning and handoff. Both physically double-check items together before Worker 1 (or both) brings verified waste to G3 (Waste Area), then they return for more. This mirrored, parallel, and cross-over workflow ensures the two workers repeatedly traverse and occupy nearly the entire robot route (G19 to G3), especially clustering at the G7/G4 midpoint handoff/sorting stage. The density and redundancy requirements organically minimize the average distance between the robot and both workers for the entirety of the robot's fixed waste-transfer task.
